body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?
body_html:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter what. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually like to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

  • I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

  • Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

  • I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

  • I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

title: I think I'm quitting everything

body: I suck at everything too, the solution is to continue doing what you enjoy and stop comparing yourself to others. The vast majority of people are never going to accomplish anything great, it's a waste of time to try imo
body_html: I suck at everything too, the solution is to continue doing what you enjoy and stop comparing yourself to others. The vast majority of people are never going to accomplish anything great, it's a waste of time to try imo

author.bio: You've come here to dig up dirt, probably because you lost an argument and are now resorting to petty tactics. My opinions may offend, in a free society that's acceptable. Much love and peace.
author.bio_html: You've come here to dig up dirt, probably because you lost an argument and are now resorting to petty tactics. My opinions may offend, in a free society that's acceptable. Much love and peace.

body:
Continue to develop your knowledge of the world. A new hobby or interest will come along eventually. Being good at something and enjoying it are two entirely different things.

Plenty of people are terrible at fishing, but they still go out there and fish and enjoy the experience tremendously. Hold yourself accountable to your own standards and life becomes easier.

body:
Suck it up buttercup.

Just kidding. Your lack of creativity could really be a lack of interest in the things you enjoy which I know is a symptom of depression. Also, with programming it really is hard to remember syntax so I feel you there. You also don't have to be good at stuff to enjoy it if you don't put that pressure on yourself. Just taking walks outside and hiking is something that is really enjoyable that doesn't require any skill.

Also, I don't know if you are religious or not but I believe that your value is not in whether or not you are good at something, but that your value comes from the inherent worth that you have as a God created being. If you have any more questions about God feel free to ask away. I would suggest starting reading the book of John https://www.esv.org/John+1/

"But he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore I will boast all the more gladly of my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ may rest upon me. For the sake of Christ, then, I am content with weaknesses, insults, hardships, persecutions, and calamities. For when I am weak, then I am strong." 2 Corinthians 12:9-10

body:
I have similar feelings in that I'm out of place in the world. All of my personal views are hated, and all the things I find interest in are going to shit. I feel unmotivated because it feels like the entire game has be rigged to the point that I can't get in anymore.

At this point I'm just plain done. There's nothing worth fighting for anymore. I'm just doing full normie at this point.

body:
> I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

It will probably take me more time than that, after programming for > 10 years. Try something else than web frontends.

EDIT: Also yeah, symptoms of depression as others said. You should see a doctor. Depression can't be cured by talking to a counselor or "pulling yourself together". It's only cured with medication. It may actually be the *reason* you're learning slowly.

parent.body:
> I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

It will probably take me more time than that, after programming for > 10 years. Try something else than web frontends.

EDIT: Also yeah, symptoms of depression as others said. You should see a doctor. Depression can't be cured by talking to a counselor or "pulling yourself together". It's only cured with medication. It may actually be the *reason* you're learning slowly.

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
> There will always be someone better than you at any given thing

Yeah, but usually it's because they're more into it and have more experience. Also, it's not just some people, it's literally everyone.

> Catch up on some reading or entertainment. There's no shame in enjoying yourself and relaxing for a bit if you're burnt out on your hobbies.

I'm not burned out with them, I just can't manage them. The other problem is that for me, those hobbies pretty much *are* my entertainment.

Why is my brain miswired so badly that I am driven to the very things I'm not cut out for?
body_html:

body:
>no matter how much I practice 

I'll be blunt with you, that's just a common excuse to stop practicing once you get frustrated, the reality is the more you practice the more you get better no matter what field you try to get into. So my recommendation is to keep practicing even if it feels hard, and it'll continue getting progressively easier the more you do it.

parent.body:
Continue to develop your knowledge of the world. A new hobby or interest will come along eventually. Being good at something and enjoying it are two entirely different things.

Plenty of people are terrible at fishing, but they still go out there and fish and enjoy the experience tremendously. Hold yourself accountable to your own standards and life becomes easier.

  • I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

  • Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

  • I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

  • I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?
post.title: I think I'm quitting everything

What you said here is potentially the most destructive advice you could have given to the OP.

body:
If you are having fun, keep doing it as a hobby. If not, feel free to move on. You can be interested in whatever you like. Sometimes things you wish you were good at maybe you aren’t. If this relates to a job, find something you can both be good at and somewhat enjoy. 

I remember trying to learn Blender, I hated doing it, but I wanted to achieve something with it, so I worked until I did and then I moved on to something else. Other things I am good at were often still frustrating or hard at certain times, but the enjoyment/achievement outweighed that. 

I also think creation is balanced with consumption, when you feel alive, inspired, thought provoked, curious it can motivate you to make. So maybe just go enjoy other things for a bit without pressure.
body_html:
If you are having fun, keep doing it as a hobby. If not, feel free to move on. You can be interested in whatever you like. Sometimes things you wish you were good at maybe you aren’t. If this relates to a job, find something you can both be good at and somewhat enjoy.

I remember trying to learn Blender, I hated doing it, but I wanted to achieve something with it, so I worked until I did and then I moved on to something else. Other things I am good at were often still frustrating or hard at certain times, but the enjoyment/achievement outweighed that.

I also think creation is balanced with consumption, when you feel alive, inspired, thought provoked, curious it can motivate you to make. So maybe just go enjoy other things for a bit without pressure.

  • I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
Thank you, this is the only answer that is much of any help.

However I am not new to this, I know all these things and it's yet another thing I absolutely suck at, I can never see things that way. I am never thankful for anything like I should be. Instead, I'm envious, stingy, greedy, selfish, angry, and pretty much every bad thing you could think of. I usually do bad things carelessly and rarely consider how it affects others. It's not a I tried my best and failed situation, I feel like I don't have much motivation to care about anything but myself. I don't like that but I'm just never willing to get out of that mindset for some reason. I must be the most selfish person on the planet, and I'm usually skilled enough to make other people *think* I'm a good person even though I'm not. In addition, I'm not even willing to mission to anyone because I don't want to risk losing friends or even just acquaintances over it, otherwise I'd have probably mentioned it more than just in this one comment because I actually think about it a lot. You can see how even in this comment I avoided referring to anything by name, that's literally how fucking low I am. So I'm also a huge coward on top of being extremely self-centered. That should tell you enough about where I belong. I've tried to change my heart many times before but I never have been able to, because I'm never willing to care about anything but myself. I'm literally bad in every way and I don't know what to do about it.

parent.body:
Suck it up buttercup.

Just kidding. Your lack of creativity could really be a lack of interest in the things you enjoy which I know is a symptom of depression. Also, with programming it really is hard to remember syntax so I feel you there. You also don't have to be good at stuff to enjoy it if you don't put that pressure on yourself. Just taking walks outside and hiking is something that is really enjoyable that doesn't require any skill.

Also, I don't know if you are religious or not but I believe that your value is not in whether or not you are good at something, but that your value comes from the inherent worth that you have as a God created being. If you have any more questions about God feel free to ask away. I would suggest starting reading the book of John https://www.esv.org/John+1/

"But he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore I will boast all the more gladly of my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ may rest upon me. For the sake of Christ, then, I am content with weaknesses, insults, hardships, persecutions, and calamities. For when I am weak, then I am strong." 2 Corinthians 12:9-10

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

body:
> If you are having fun, keep doing it as a hobby. If not, feel free to move on. You can be interested in whatever you like.

I can't enjoy other things, because I can't do them either! I listed everything I have an interest in, there is mild interest in a few other things but I'm even bad at those. I would be having fun at all those things, but I can't even do enough to have fun with them.

> Sometimes things you wish you were good at maybe you aren’t.

Well that's pretty much my problem. Still seems to be absolutely zero solution to that, I suppose it's just bad luck that my brain isn't wired for the things I like to do like it is for most people. And there's probably not a fucking thing I can do about that.

> If this relates to a job, find something you can both be good at and somewhat enjoy.

Pffft no, good luck with that if I'm not even cut out for one hobby.

> So maybe just go enjoy other things for a bit without pressure.

Again, I don't really have other things to do, they're all the same. And as I said before I'm not too intrigued by the idea of laying around watching tv and sleeping all day, I know a lot of people are but I'm not.

parent.body:
If you are having fun, keep doing it as a hobby. If not, feel free to move on. You can be interested in whatever you like. Sometimes things you wish you were good at maybe you aren’t. If this relates to a job, find something you can both be good at and somewhat enjoy. 

I remember trying to learn Blender, I hated doing it, but I wanted to achieve something with it, so I worked until I did and then I moved on to something else. Other things I am good at were often still frustrating or hard at certain times, but the enjoyment/achievement outweighed that. 

I also think creation is balanced with consumption, when you feel alive, inspired, thought provoked, curious it can motivate you to make. So maybe just go enjoy other things for a bit without pressure.
parent.body_html:

I also think creation is balanced with consumption, when you feel alive, inspired, thought provoked, curious it can motivate you to make. So maybe just go enjoy other things for a bit without pressure.

body: Well this isn't about a career as much, I just like to do things and make stuff for fun but I'm never good enough to do any of that in a reasonable amount of time. Having fun with the stuff other people already made is cool but it only goes so far before wanting to make things of my own. I just want to be able to do things for myself without having to rely on other people for everything, and it's frustrating not being able to while seeing everyone I know doing it with ease in multiple different areas.

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
I practice a lot for years, and my situation remains the same. While I see everyone else with the same or less experience doing so much more so much easier, so I know something's not working about just practicing a lot. I literally spend all my time a lot of days practicing things, so I don't know how I can really practice more, and I remain worse than mediocre.

It kinda feels like I'm wired to do a bunch of stuff but something's not working right and my capabilities don't work as a result.

parent.body:
>no matter how much I practice 

I'll be blunt with you, that's just a common excuse to stop practicing once you get frustrated, the reality is the more you practice the more you get better no matter what field you try to get into. So my recommendation is to keep practicing even if it feels hard, and it'll continue getting progressively easier the more you do it.

body:
> What you said here is potentially the most destructive advice you could have given to the OP.

The only advice I have given him is to see a doctor. How is that destructive? I didn't tell him to go buy antidepressants without a prescription.

> I couldn't disagree more vehemently. Medication is not the answer to depression. Lifestyle change is the answer. Change your body. Change your mind. There are a million ways to do it.

Ok, I exaggerated it a bit so OP doesn't hesitate to see a doctor. :) But I'll set a few things straight in your "vehement disagreement" anyway.

It's debated whether depression is a physical or a mental disorder. It may have either or both causes. If it's the former then "changing your body" (proper exercise and diet) and medication are the answers. "Changing your mind" isn't going to do a thing. If it's the latter then and only then you're correct.

body:
Most of the world are consumers of entertainment rather than creators.  The ones that are creators had a drive their entire lives to develop a talent so they can get these ideas out of their heads and into the physical world, where they are consumed by the muggles.  

I recommend that you focus on whatever the one thing is you like the most.  I’ve been an animator for 30 years and I’ve hit plateaus, and gotten into ruts where I wasn’t learning, or even forgetting things I had already learned.  Sometimes I need inspiration, so I’ll go to a trade event to be around ‘my people’, or I’ll read a biography or a technical book by an animator.  Sometimes you can only progress so far by yourself till you hit a wall.  Find people that are doing what you are interested in and make contact.
body_html:
Most of the world are consumers of entertainment rather than creators. The ones that are creators had a drive their entire lives to develop a talent so they can get these ideas out of their heads and into the physical world, where they are consumed by the muggles.

I recommend that you focus on whatever the one thing is you like the most. I’ve been an animator for 30 years and I’ve hit plateaus, and gotten into ruts where I wasn’t learning, or even forgetting things I had already learned. Sometimes I need inspiration, so I’ll go to a trade event to be around ‘my people’, or I’ll read a biography or a technical book by an animator. Sometimes you can only progress so far by yourself till you hit a wall. Find people that are doing what you are interested in and make contact.

body:
I think you just might be dissatisfied. Do you feel overly pressured by the gap you perceive between you and other people? Perspective can be a lot and can destroy your enjoyment. It can be hard to balance discipline and enjoyment. The main goal of a hobby is to have fun. Learning should be fun. 

Like playing games should just be enjoyable. 

And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better. 

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge. 

I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that. But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

Pffft no, good luck with that if I'm not even cut out for one hobby.

Again, I don't really have other things to do, they're all the same. And as I said before I'm not too intrigued by the idea of laying around watching tv and sleeping all day, I know a lot of people are but I'm not.

  • I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?
post.title: I think I'm quitting everything

body:
> While I can't speak to all your hobbies I can tell you for sure there are worse programmers than you. Like **WAY** worse.

Because most of them aren't actually interested in it. They just do it because it pays good money, so they learn the bare minimum and forget about it after their work shift is over. Everyone I know who actually likes it can set a whole mostly-working program base up in the same time it takes me to get one tiny component working correctly, perhaps even less. They can do it in multiple languages too, even the ones they don't use a lot or don't like, better than I can in my main language. This is all after the same amount and type of experience as I have, often less, and for the same exact reasons.

> Well then just keep doing them I guess. If you're getting enjoyment out of it, that has its own value.

Well that's kind of hard to do when it takes forever to get anything done. And it feels even worse seeing everyone else do it 10x over so much easier. A lot of them are very similar and like-minded to me too, just good at the things they do instead of bad. I guess my interests just aren't aligned with my abilities for some reason, if I have much of any abilities at all that is. That's a pretty tough mismatch to have.

> I mean you made that triangular political compass, that's something. Just because it's not groundbreaking doesn't mean it's not an accomplishment. I enjoyed it.

Yeah, but that's like the only useful thing I've done in a year or two, and it still has many problems. And don't think I just whipped that together in an hour either, though it'd have taken most programmers 5 minutes I spent many hours, perhaps a day even on it (in total time, not including time I wasn't working on it). It was extremely basic HTML. And I still can't even come up with a good design for the site.

I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

parent.body:
Most of the world are consumers of entertainment rather than creators.  The ones that are creators had a drive their entire lives to develop a talent so they can get these ideas out of their heads and into the physical world, where they are consumed by the muggles.  

I recommend that you focus on whatever the one thing is you like the most.  I’ve been an animator for 30 years and I’ve hit plateaus, and gotten into ruts where I wasn’t learning, or even forgetting things I had already learned.  Sometimes I need inspiration, so I’ll go to a trade event to be around ‘my people’, or I’ll read a biography or a technical book by an animator.  Sometimes you can only progress so far by yourself till you hit a wall.  Find people that are doing what you are interested in and make contact.
parent.body_html:
Most of the world are consumers of entertainment rather than creators. The ones that are creators had a drive their entire lives to develop a talent so they can get these ideas out of their heads and into the physical world, where they are consumed by the muggles.

I recommend that you focus on whatever the one thing is you like the most. I’ve been an animator for 30 years and I’ve hit plateaus, and gotten into ruts where I wasn’t learning, or even forgetting things I had already learned. Sometimes I need inspiration, so I’ll go to a trade event to be around ‘my people’, or I’ll read a biography or a technical book by an animator. Sometimes you can only progress so far by yourself till you hit a wall. Find people that are doing what you are interested in and make contact.

body:
> Do you feel overly pressured by the gap you perceive between you and other people?

Well I had a lot of frustrations before too, but thought that might just be how things are. But now seeing everyone else *not* having all those same issues proves that's not how it should be going, which does make it worse.

> And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better.

True, I suppose I could do more of that but it still wouldn't satisfy my main interests. Though it's much better than nothing, so at least I'm not completely lost like I was. I know people who just do that and are still happy.

> I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

I'm not really a consumer as much as a creator, at least as far as my desire goes (certainly not in my abilities). If you're getting more at the sports mindset though I'm not at all unfamiliar with that, I know how to think that way.

> I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that.

Well you tried. That's all you can do. I don't think every problem can be solved, and this may be one of them.

> But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

Hopefully, probably even, though it doesn't seem like that'll happen any time soon, so in the meantime I'm not sure what to do. I don't even know if I have any talents at all, I can't even acquire any very well, most people can at least do that even if they don't start out at a high level. I guess I'll just have to wait it out until something comes along.
body_html:
Do you feel overly pressured by the gap you perceive between you and other people?

Well I had a lot of frustrations before too, but thought that might just be how things are. But now seeing everyone else not having all those same issues proves that's not how it should be going, which does make it worse.

And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better.

True, I suppose I could do more of that but it still wouldn't satisfy my main interests. Though it's much better than nothing, so at least I'm not completely lost like I was. I know people who just do that and are still happy.

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

I'm not really a consumer as much as a creator, at least as far as my desire goes (certainly not in my abilities). If you're getting more at the sports mindset though I'm not at all unfamiliar with that, I know how to think that way.

I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that.

Well you tried. That's all you can do. I don't think every problem can be solved, and this may be one of them.

But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

Hopefully, probably even, though it doesn't seem like that'll happen any time soon, so in the meantime I'm not sure what to do. I don't even know if I have any talents at all, I can't even acquire any very well, most people can at least do that even if they don't start out at a high level. I guess I'll just have to wait it out until something comes along.

parent.body:
I think you just might be dissatisfied. Do you feel overly pressured by the gap you perceive between you and other people? Perspective can be a lot and can destroy your enjoyment. It can be hard to balance discipline and enjoyment. The main goal of a hobby is to have fun. Learning should be fun. 

Like playing games should just be enjoyable. 

And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better. 

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge. 

I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that. But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

Like playing games should just be enjoyable.

And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better.

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that. But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

parent.body:
> What you said here is potentially the most destructive advice you could have given to the OP.

The only advice I have given him is to see a doctor. How is that destructive? I didn't tell him to go buy antidepressants without a prescription.

> I couldn't disagree more vehemently. Medication is not the answer to depression. Lifestyle change is the answer. Change your body. Change your mind. There are a million ways to do it.

Ok, I exaggerated it a bit so OP doesn't hesitate to see a doctor. :) But I'll set a few things straight in your "vehement disagreement" anyway.

It's debated whether depression is a physical or a mental disorder. It may have either or both causes. If it's the former then "changing your body" (proper exercise and diet) and medication are the answers. "Changing your mind" isn't going to do a thing. If it's the latter then and only then you're correct.

body:
Well if you feel alone in your frustrations, I don’t think that’s true, I think a lot people get feelings like yours. I’ve felt them myself before. I think social media comparisons can do that. If had seen how good some people were, I may never have taken any pride in my own work to start out. Some people be like hey that’s 4 things you like, I only have 1. 

Don’t be too negative~ it sounds like you are too young for that.

parent.body:
> Do you feel overly pressured by the gap you perceive between you and other people?

Well I had a lot of frustrations before too, but thought that might just be how things are. But now seeing everyone else *not* having all those same issues proves that's not how it should be going, which does make it worse.

> And by enjoying things I don’t mean just watch tv. I mean like going on a hike, riding a bike, learning to cook better.

True, I suppose I could do more of that but it still wouldn't satisfy my main interests. Though it's much better than nothing, so at least I'm not completely lost like I was. I know people who just do that and are still happy.

> I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

I'm not really a consumer as much as a creator, at least as far as my desire goes (certainly not in my abilities). If you're getting more at the sports mindset though I'm not at all unfamiliar with that, I know how to think that way.

> I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that.

Well you tried. That's all you can do. I don't think every problem can be solved, and this may be one of them.

> But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

Hopefully, probably even, though it doesn't seem like that'll happen any time soon, so in the meantime I'm not sure what to do. I don't even know if I have any talents at all, I can't even acquire any very well, most people can at least do that even if they don't start out at a high level. I guess I'll just have to wait it out until something comes along.
parent.body_html:

True, I suppose I could do more of that but it still wouldn't satisfy my main interests. Though it's much better than nothing, so at least I'm not completely lost like I was. I know people who just do that and are still happy.

I don’t know if you like anime, but I recommend watching a sports anime. The characters/players have to deal with mental strength and resiliency. Perspective has a lot do with their ability to grow and perform. Redefining an obstacle as an intriguing challenge.

I'm not really a consumer as much as a creator, at least as far as my desire goes (certainly not in my abilities). If you're getting more at the sports mindset though I'm not at all unfamiliar with that, I know how to think that way.

I don’t think I can give too much more advice than that.

Well you tried. That's all you can do. I don't think every problem can be solved, and this may be one of them.

But I pray that something changes so you can be delighted by what interests you. And pray that God may also lead you to another new hobby that is more easily and naturally suited to your personal talents.

Hopefully, probably even, though it doesn't seem like that'll happen any time soon, so in the meantime I'm not sure what to do. I don't even know if I have any talents at all, I can't even acquire any very well, most people can at least do that even if they don't start out at a high level. I guess I'll just have to wait it out until something comes along.

parent.body:
Well if you feel alone in your frustrations, I don’t think that’s true, I think a lot people get feelings like yours. I’ve felt them myself before. I think social media comparisons can do that. If had seen how good some people were, I may never have taken any pride in my own work to start out. Some people be like hey that’s 4 things you like, I only have 1. 

Don’t be too negative~ it sounds like you are too young for that.

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
> Have you tried therapy? I have not so this isn't a suggestion, I'm just curious. It sounds like you have some issues they might help you with. I think in another thread you told me you might have ADHD?

None of that stuff has ever helped me with this. It's all a gimmick that can make you pretty good at *looking* like you feel better, but all of those "magical remedies" do absolutely nothing as far as actually helping it for real.

> Is this after programming specifically in javascript for 4+ years, and you are familiar with all the additions in recent versions of javascript?

I have been programming for about 8 years now. I haven't done a ton of JS, but neither have a lot of the other programmers and they are still quite productive with it. It doesn't really matter though, because my problems that take me hours to solve are usually just a single fucking loop that doesn't touch on many of the language features, certainly not the newer ones.

> Honestly this sounds like a result of your mental health more than anything. It can really hinder your creativity.

I actually feel like it's the other way around, if this is actually severe enough to be called a mental health issue it was probably caused *by* that.

> Consider trying to eat better, drinking lots of water, and exercising.

I already do :/

> I sincerely hope you overcome your issues.

Thanks :)
body_html:
Have you tried therapy? I have not so this isn't a suggestion, I'm just curious. It sounds like you have some issues they might help you with. I think in another thread you told me you might have ADHD?

None of that stuff has ever helped me with this. It's all a gimmick that can make you pretty good at looking like you feel better, but all of those "magical remedies" do absolutely nothing as far as actually helping it for real.

Is this after programming specifically in javascript for 4+ years, and you are familiar with all the additions in recent versions of javascript?

I have been programming for about 8 years now. I haven't done a ton of JS, but neither have a lot of the other programmers and they are still quite productive with it. It doesn't really matter though, because my problems that take me hours to solve are usually just a single fucking loop that doesn't touch on many of the language features, certainly not the newer ones.

Honestly this sounds like a result of your mental health more than anything. It can really hinder your creativity.

I actually feel like it's the other way around, if this is actually severe enough to be called a mental health issue it was probably caused by that.

Consider trying to eat better, drinking lots of water, and exercising.

I already do :/

I sincerely hope you overcome your issues.

Thanks :)

body:
I think know you. I think i know the state of your being. If I had to guess it feels like climbing up an endless mineshaft, in the pitch black, on a ladder where some of the rungs are missing. your eyes see the mistakes and your brain cant fix them? never get that rush of enjoyment form a project. because you could do it better next time? 

How close am I?

Do you know who Alan Watts is?

body:
It takes 1000 hours to become good at anything. Anything at all. So if you get out a calculator (I suck at math, never will be good at it) then lets say you decide to make one of your hobbies like a job. You decide to practice a particular programming skill or drawing for 40 hours per week, five days a week, 8 hours per day. It would still take you 25 weeks to master anything, or about 6 months. Since we both know no one can do that (we have to work sometime, to make money for our hobby), then lets say you spent 2 hours per day (that's a lot of hours when you're working), 5x a week trying to master a skill. It would take you 100 weeks or 1.9 YEARS to become a master at anything. 

I think you're giving up too soon. 

I also think you're putting too much pressure on yourself. Do you enjoy it? Then do it. Who cares if you're perfect at it? Who cares if you're good at it? I love to draw--I suck at drawing but I keep buying sketch pads and pencils and charcoals and trying anyway, because I don't care if I'm good at it. I like it. 

Also look for more things. I can do 3 things really well. I can write. I can speed walk (like seriously, Olympic level if it was an Olympic sport, which it isn't so it's useless) and Land Navigation. Give me a compass, a protractor, and a map and I can get anywhere. But who the hell cares when we have cars, and phones with maps on them that tell us exactly where to go and how long it will take with a car/bus or walking? They're about the most useless skills on the planet. Most people wouldn't even consider land navigation a talent (it is) and even if it is a talent, its utterly useless to everyone. Maybe you just haven't found your talent yet. 

(I also seriously suck at video games, always have, dont' care, I still play)

I also think you're putting too much pressure on yourself. Do you enjoy it? Then do it. Who cares if you're perfect at it? Who cares if you're good at it? I love to draw--I suck at drawing but I keep buying sketch pads and pencils and charcoals and trying anyway, because I don't care if I'm good at it. I like it.

Also look for more things. I can do 3 things really well. I can write. I can speed walk (like seriously, Olympic level if it was an Olympic sport, which it isn't so it's useless) and Land Navigation. Give me a compass, a protractor, and a map and I can get anywhere. But who the hell cares when we have cars, and phones with maps on them that tell us exactly where to go and how long it will take with a car/bus or walking? They're about the most useless skills on the planet. Most people wouldn't even consider land navigation a talent (it is) and even if it is a talent, its utterly useless to everyone. Maybe you just haven't found your talent yet.

(I also seriously suck at video games, always have, dont' care, I still play)

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
A few things to ponder. As much as you may suck at everything else, you are at least aware of your deficiencies. Having said that, I think you take it too far. Is it not possible that you simply haven't found what you're good at yet?

Also, these things you lack in, are they really what determine a persons worth? I know a lot of programmers the world would be better off without having. Even if you are mentally handicapped at coding, that doesn't really mean much except that coding isn't for you.  I've worked as a Linux Administrator maintaining image processing and storage servers at a satellite imagery company, and though I wasn't at all top of the chain in knowledge, I think I could hold my own in a server maintenance competition. Having said that, I rarely get past hello word applications, and the most complex thing I've "coded" is a 90's looking html page. Am I any less capable of maintaining good uptime on the servers? I don't think so, though it would surely help to be able to script/automate things, what one lacks in one are can be compensated for in another.

Having said that, and without making this post too long, what if its not just IT comprehensively that you weren't made for? We all have different strengths and weaknesses, and we all find ourselves in situations where we doubt our competency on the subject. There is nothing wrong with saying "I guess its not for me."

I would love to talk at length about this, so if its suicide you're implying, at least grant me to opportunity to speak with you more before making any drastic decisions. If you judge the value of a fish by how far up a tree it can climb you will be often disappointed.

body:
You've had lots of great general answers here, so I'll take on your points instead.

- "I can't program hardly at all. [...] loop through DOM elements [...]"
Don't drink from the firehose :). Poorly designed languages and bad APIs are NOT your fault. The current state of software development is garbage. I feel awful for Gen Z / the newer folks getting into it. You are sold a sterilized view of what serious programming is about, but most software is a hot mess. Take a break from producing code for other people. If that means skipping assignments/work/etc, do it. In my case, I saved what little desire I had left to code by writing an emulator front-end. It was totally superfluous, but it worked exactly the way I wanted it to, and it was fun to make. YOU NEED SIMILAR PROJECTS. Small ones that only you care about. Programming, in terms of a career/hobby, is a marathon - not a sprint. Don't let agile warriors fool you :). Fuck the latest JavaScript API. You will learn it when you need it and then forget it. Just make sure you actually know how to write loops as a matter of principle - basic logical competencies of the field - and learn your limitations. Your co-workers will always help you out if you aren't trying to cover up imperfections.

- "Can't draw. [...]"
Do people who suck at math feel bad about using calculators? I guess they could get worked up over it, but why? When doing artsy stuff, find tools that compensate for your blind spots / skill gaps. Think of how many talented artists couldn't use watercolor to save their life. The issue with lines? Draw them in MSPaint with the line tool so you can't mess up, print it, and work from that? As for perspective, why not look for plugins that can resize a selected area *relative* to another? I don't have good answers here, but I've got to believe there's a workaround for being frustrum-impaired :). Take a step back from trying to draw, and instead spend some time looking for affordable, sensible tools that might help you.

- "I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. [...] playing Minecraft [...]"
Creativity waxes and wanes directly in proportion with your available energy and level of boredom. As a developer who is trying to draw and create their own virtual game worlds, your mind is literally never experiencing a break. You can deal with this in one of two ways that I'm aware of -- either by A) *scheduling* break periods into your life to let your mind wander, or by B) finding a philosophical place of contentment where creativity isn't a metric you use to judge yourself. Also, stop playing Minecraft. You can't be inspired by playing with blocks as an adult, unless your IQ is less than that of a block. If you're actively looking for inspiration from video game media, try a story driven game with adult narratives, a low-pressure music-driven game, or something experimental. Agony, Thumper, and Outer Wilds come to mind as interesting games that might bore you in the right kind of way :).

- "I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games."
Consider that the rules for every game are written by a specific developer. Why tie your sense of worth to frustration in binary form? Play games that make you happy. When a developer inserts a stupid challenge and doesn't give you save states, curse the bastards and refund it. Let some other loser waste their life on "Dark Souls 6.0", or whatever.

Lastly, yes, you can have hobbies, and you already do. Hobbies are simply habits you LIKE, that you engage in with intent.

Is there anything you can do? Yes. When burnt out, re-organize your life so that you approach every day in this way:
1) Do the things you LIKE to do. Make jokes with friends; draw some crappy line art; drink a special coffee?
2) Do the things you HAVE to do. Wash yourself; feed yourself; pay your bills.
3) Do the things you WANT to do. Work on life goals; practice new skills; etc.

You will notice you are "improving" when the things you WANT to do become the things you LIKE to do. This may take several decades, but it works for everyone who works at it :).

Good luck stranger.
body_html:
You've had lots of great general answers here, so I'll take on your points instead.

  • "I can't program hardly at all. [...] loop through DOM elements [...]" Don't drink from the firehose :). Poorly designed languages and bad APIs are NOT your fault. The current state of software development is garbage. I feel awful for Gen Z / the newer folks getting into it. You are sold a sterilized view of what serious programming is about, but most software is a hot mess. Take a break from producing code for other people. If that means skipping assignments/work/etc, do it. In my case, I saved what little desire I had left to code by writing an emulator front-end. It was totally superfluous, but it worked exactly the way I wanted it to, and it was fun to make. YOU NEED SIMILAR PROJECTS. Small ones that only you care about. Programming, in terms of a career/hobby, is a marathon - not a sprint. Don't let agile warriors fool you :). Fuck the latest JavaScript API. You will learn it when you need it and then forget it. Just make sure you actually know how to write loops as a matter of principle - basic logical competencies of the field - and learn your limitations. Your co-workers will always help you out if you aren't trying to cover up imperfections.

  • "Can't draw. [...]" Do people who suck at math feel bad about using calculators? I guess they could get worked up over it, but why? When doing artsy stuff, find tools that compensate for your blind spots / skill gaps. Think of how many talented artists couldn't use watercolor to save their life. The issue with lines? Draw them in MSPaint with the line tool so you can't mess up, print it, and work from that? As for perspective, why not look for plugins that can resize a selected area relative to another? I don't have good answers here, but I've got to believe there's a workaround for being frustrum-impaired :). Take a step back from trying to draw, and instead spend some time looking for affordable, sensible tools that might help you.

  • "I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. [...] playing Minecraft [...]" Creativity waxes and wanes directly in proportion with your available energy and level of boredom. As a developer who is trying to draw and create their own virtual game worlds, your mind is literally never experiencing a break. You can deal with this in one of two ways that I'm aware of -- either by A) scheduling break periods into your life to let your mind wander, or by B) finding a philosophical place of contentment where creativity isn't a metric you use to judge yourself. Also, stop playing Minecraft. You can't be inspired by playing with blocks as an adult, unless your IQ is less than that of a block. If you're actively looking for inspiration from video game media, try a story driven game with adult narratives, a low-pressure music-driven game, or something experimental. Agony, Thumper, and Outer Wilds come to mind as interesting games that might bore you in the right kind of way :).

  • "I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games." Consider that the rules for every game are written by a specific developer. Why tie your sense of worth to frustration in binary form? Play games that make you happy. When a developer inserts a stupid challenge and doesn't give you save states, curse the bastards and refund it. Let some other loser waste their life on "Dark Souls 6.0", or whatever.

Lastly, yes, you can have hobbies, and you already do. Hobbies are simply habits you LIKE, that you engage in with intent.

Is there anything you can do? Yes. When burnt out, re-organize your life so that you approach every day in this way:

  1. Do the things you LIKE to do. Make jokes with friends; draw some crappy line art; drink a special coffee?
  2. Do the things you HAVE to do. Wash yourself; feed yourself; pay your bills.
  3. Do the things you WANT to do. Work on life goals; practice new skills; etc.

You will notice you are "improving" when the things you WANT to do become the things you LIKE to do. This may take several decades, but it works for everyone who works at it :).

Good luck stranger.

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
With respect to software development, this is simply incorrect and I would like to scrub this invalid opinion from the field. If you are practicing endlessly, you have skipped cardinal rule #1 of being a good developer - which is to say, automating away problems. Repetition is the computer's job. Your job as the developer is to master that process effectively. Memorizing a library or trying to lock in the best way to do sorts is, therefore, counter productive.

What the old hats refer to as "practice" is actually obsessive-compulsive interest driving them to learn endlessly. That's fine :). I happen to be one of those 16-hour-a-day freaks myself. However, I don't pretend for a second that the pattern of learning I went through was healthy, and I don't recommend that new people follow the same path I did. I wish developers would stop perpetuating this bullshit notion of pseudo-machismo because it cripples the industry's capacity to invite genuine talent who aren't "tryhards" by nature.

What the old hats refer to as "practice" is actually obsessive-compulsive interest driving them to learn endlessly. That's fine :). I happen to be one of those 16-hour-a-day freaks myself. parent.body:
>no matter how much I practice 

I'll be blunt with you, that's just a common excuse to stop practicing once you get frustrated, the reality is the more you practice the more you get better no matter what field you try to get into. So my recommendation is to keep practicing even if it feels hard, and it'll continue getting progressively easier the more you do it.

body:
This sounds a lot like depression to me, at least the way I experienced it. I lost interest in everything I used to like and felt like I sucked at everything too. 

I’m in no way completely fixed now, but I think the biggest factor in helping me make peace with my life was tripping on psychedelics. Psilocybin mushrooms and LSD showed me that we live in a crazy, amazing world that has too much to offer for me to justify giving up on everything. I worked through a lot of things during those trips, and I think I’m a better person because of them. 

Psychedelics might not be for everyone, but I really do think they’re worth exploring. Recent research has been revealing how much even one dose can help with depression and other mental illnesses (though you don’t need to have a mental illness to see the benefits). 

I also think you should talk to your doctor about the way you’ve been feeling, and maybe even see a psychiatrist or psychologist. Prescribed antidepressants can help a lot too, if this really is depression. 

Also I really liked the triangular political compass you made, enough to check out your profile here and look for other cool things you might’ve done. Even if you don’t think it’s impressive, it’s reached and affected a lot of people that do. You’ve left a mark on the world with that alone, which is more than I can say about anything I’ve done.

body:
I _think_ I know what you mean, and my personal advice is this: Try different things, and see what sticks. I know that it's very easy to say, but I believe anyone can do it. Try fishing, try horse riding, try learning some kind of instrument, try paintball (if it's open rn). 

Sticking to the same few things will make you devoid of creativity (as you said), and from what I assume is that you're almost bored. 

Also, those might be the symptoms of depression. Not everyone who has depression knows it, and probably even has the same "symptoms". I've heard examples of people with depression who are shit at everything, but "are usually happy".

Is there anything I can do?

body:
I know for me it sometimes feels like a negative record of all my flaws in playing on repeat in my head. Getting out of it is much easier said than done but I have a couple suggestions.

>I am never thankful for anything like I should be.

You can change that. Take a minute to write down one thing you are thankful for every day. It only takes a few minutes but it has an impact on your perspective.

> I've tried to change my heart many times before but I never have been able to, because I'm never willing to care about anything but myself.

This one is a little harder but the same concept applies. Each day, write about a good thing you did for another person.
If you find you can’t think of anything, find something you can do and then write it down. 

Some ideas:
Volunteer your time to support a cause you care about.

Pay for someone else’s food at a restaurant or fast food place.

Clean up or do household chores for a family member without taking credit.



No one is good all the time but it’s never too late to be a better person.

Good luck

I've tried to change my heart many times before but I never have been able to, because I'm never willing to care about anything but myself.

This one is a little harder but the same concept applies. Each day, write about a good thing you did for another person. If you find you can’t think of anything, find something you can do and then write it down.

Pay for someone else’s food at a restaurant or fast food place.

Clean up or do household chores for a family member without taking credit.

No one is good all the time but it’s never too late to be a better person.

Good luck

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

> This sounds a lot like depression to me, at least the way I experienced it. I lost interest in everything I used to like and felt like I sucked at everything too.

I don't think so. I suck at everything but I *definitely* haven't lost interest. I know people who have and I'm not like that.

Also doing drugs is *not* a solution. That's just running away from the problem, and in most ways probably makes it even worse. And it's also very risky. Not an option for me.

parent.body:
This sounds a lot like depression to me, at least the way I experienced it. I lost interest in everything I used to like and felt like I sucked at everything too. 

I’m in no way completely fixed now, but I think the biggest factor in helping me make peace with my life was tripping on psychedelics. Psilocybin mushrooms and LSD showed me that we live in a crazy, amazing world that has too much to offer for me to justify giving up on everything. I worked through a lot of things during those trips, and I think I’m a better person because of them. 

Psychedelics might not be for everyone, but I really do think they’re worth exploring. Recent research has been revealing how much even one dose can help with depression and other mental illnesses (though you don’t need to have a mental illness to see the benefits). 

I also think you should talk to your doctor about the way you’ve been feeling, and maybe even see a psychiatrist or psychologist. Prescribed antidepressants can help a lot too, if this really is depression. 

Also I really liked the triangular political compass you made, enough to check out your profile here and look for other cool things you might’ve done. Even if you don’t think it’s impressive, it’s reached and affected a lot of people that do. You’ve left a mark on the world with that alone, which is more than I can say about anything I’ve done.

body:
> It takes 1000 hours to become good at anything. Anything at all. So if you get out a calculator (I suck at math, never will be good at it) then lets say you decide to make one of your hobbies like a job. You decide to practice a particular programming skill or drawing for 40 hours per week, five days a week, 8 hours per day. It would still take you 25 weeks to master anything, or about 6 months. Since we both know no one can do that (we have to work sometime, to make money for our hobby), then lets say you spent 2 hours per day (that's a lot of hours when you're working), 5x a week trying to master a skill. It would take you 100 weeks or 1.9 YEARS to become a master at anything.

I've been doing it for a very long time, longer than some of the other devs I've talked to.

> I also think you're putting too much pressure on yourself. Do you enjoy it?

I would but I can never get anything accomplished in a reasonable amount of time.

> Maybe you just haven't found your talent yet.

Well I can already tell it's either pointless or something I don't like, so why even bother with it?

It would take you 100 weeks or 1.9 YEARS to become a master at anything.

I've been doing it for a very long time, longer than some of the other devs I've talked to.
